faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.description: Common questions about ROI calculations and investment analysis

items.title: What is ROI in marketing?
items.description: ROI (Return on Investment) measures the profitability of your marketing investments by comparing revenue generated to costs incurred. A positive ROI means you're earning more than you're spending.

items.title: How do you calculate ROI?
items.description: ROI is calculated using the formula: ROI = ((Revenue - Cost) / Cost) × 100%. For example, if you spend $5,000 and generate $10,000 in revenue, your ROI is 100%.

items.title: What's a good ROI for marketing campaigns?
items.description: A good ROI varies by industry and campaign type. Generally, a 5:1 ratio (500% ROI) is considered strong, meaning for every $1 spent, you earn $5 back. However, acceptable ROI depends on your business goals and profit margins.

items.title: Why is ROI important for businesses?
items.description: ROI helps businesses evaluate the effectiveness of their marketing investments, compare different campaigns, allocate budgets efficiently, and make data-driven decisions about future marketing strategies.

items.title: What's the difference between ROI and ROAS?
items.description: ROI measures overall profitability by considering all costs and profits, while ROAS (Return on Ad Spend) focuses specifically on revenue generated per dollar spent on advertising. ROAS is a subset of ROI focused on ad spending.

items.title: How can I improve my marketing ROI?
items.description: Improve ROI by targeting more qualified audiences, optimizing conversion rates, reducing acquisition costs, improving customer lifetime value, testing different channels, and continuously analyzing performance data.
